facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1951 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1951. Appeal from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment and decree dated September 4, 1946, of the Chief Court of Oudh.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated September 4, 1946, of the late Chief Court of Oudh-  number the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad, Lucknow Bench   Misra and Wallford JJ.

facts.text: Chief Court judgment in First Civil Appeal No. 139 of 1941.

facts.text: Trial court judgment dated October 23, 1941, by Civil Judge, Bahraich, in Regular Suit No. 1 of 1941.

anchor.surface_text: in First Civil Appeal No. 139 of 1941, arising out of the Judgment,and Decree dated October 23, 1941, of the Court of the Civil Judge, Bahraich, in Regular Suit No. I of 1941. Onkar Nath Srivastava for the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 7, 1952, by MUKHERJEA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1952. November 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.-This appeal is on behalf of the plaintiff

facts.text: Raja Bisheshwar Bux Singh was father of plaintiff Bajrang Bahadur and husband of defendant Bakhtraj Kuer's late husband Dhuj Singh.

anchor.surface_text: To appreciate the companytroversy between the parties to this appeal it would be necessary to state a few facts. One Raja Bisheshwar Bux Singh, the father of the plaintiff and of the defendants husband,

facts.text: Raja Bisheshwar Bux Singh succeeded to Gangwat Estate in 1925 on death of the widow of the last holder.

anchor.surface_text: was a taluqdar of Oudh, and the estate known as Gangwat Estate, to which he succeeded in 1925 on the death of the widow of the last holder, is one to which the Oudh Estates Act  I of,1869  applies.

facts.text: Gangwat Estate is governed by Oudh Estates Act I of 1869.

anchor.surface_text: is one to which the Oudh Estates Act  I of,1869  applies. Raja Bisheshwar died on 16th October, 1930, leaving behind him two sons,

facts.text: Raja Bisheshwar died on 16th October 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Raja Bisheshwar died on 16th October, 1930, leaving behind him two sons, the elder of whom, Bajrang Bahadur, is the plaintiff in the present litigation,

facts.text: Left two sons: elder Bajrang Bahadur (plaintiff), younger Dhuj Singh.

anchor.surface_text: leaving behind him two sons, the elder of whom, Bajrang Bahadur, is the plaintiff in the present litigation, while the younger, whose name was Dhuj Singh, has died since then,

facts.text: Dhuj Singh died in 1940, survived by widow Bakhtraj Kuer (defendant).

anchor.surface_text: while the younger, whose name was Dhuj Singh, has died since then, being survived by his widow Bakhtraj Kuer. who is the defendant in the suit.

facts.text: Raja Bisheshwar executed will dated 11th September 1929 bequeathing five properties (lists A and B) to Dhuj Singh for maintenance of son and heirs.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly before his death Raja Bisheshwar executed a will dated 11th September, 1929, by which five properties, described in lists A and B attached to the plaint, were bequeathed to Dhuj Singh, the younger son, by way of making provisions for the maintenance of the said son and his heirs.

facts.text: On Raja Bisheshwar's death, estate devolved to plaintiff Bajrang Bahadur as eldest son under Oudh Estates Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Raja Bisheshwar,the estatement to the plaintiff as his eldest son under the provisions of the Oudh Estates Act and Dhuj Singh got only he five properties mentioned above under the terms of his fathers will.

facts.text: Dhuj Singh had no issue.

anchor.surface_text: Dhuj Singh had numberissue of his own and on his death in 1940 disputes arose in respect of these properties

facts.text: After Dhuj Singh's death in 1940, disputes arose over the five properties between plaintiff and defendant.

anchor.surface_text: and on his death in 1940 disputes arose in respect of these properties between the plaintiff on the one land and Dhuj Singhs widow on the other.

facts.text: Plaintiff initially succeeded in mutation of his name as owner in revenue records, but appellate revenue authority set it aside and mutated in defendant's name.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff succeeded at first in having his name mutated as owner of these properties in the revenue records in place of his deceased brother, but the appellate revenue authority ultimately set aside this order and directed mutation to be made in the name of the defendant.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed Regular Suit No. 1 of 1941 for declaration of title to the five properties.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff thereupon companymenced the suit out of which this appeal arises, praying for declaration of his title to the five properties mentioned above on the allegation that they vested in him on the death of Dhuj Singh

facts.text: Four properties in list A are taluqdari properties, no dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated here that four out of these five properties have been described in list A to the plaint and there is numberdispute that they are taluqdari properties.

facts.text: Fifth property in list B is not taluqdari.

anchor.surface_text: The fifth item is set out in list B and admittedly this property is number taluqdari in its character.

facts.text: Claim to list C properties abandoned during trial.

anchor.surface_text: Besides lists A and B there is a third list, viz., Catached to the plaint, which mentions two other properties as being in possession of the defendant and in the plaint a claim was made on behalf of the plaintiff in respect to these properties as well, although they were number companyered by the will of Bisheshwar. This claim, however, was abandoned in companyrse of the trial

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed Dhuj Singh had only life interest in properties.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff really rested his case on a two-fold ground. It was averred in the first place that Dhuj Singh hadonly a life interest in the properties bequeathed to him by Bisheshwar

facts.text: Alternatively, plaintiff claimed entitlement to taluqdari properties under s.14 r/w s.22(5) Oudh Estates Act even if absolute interest.

anchor.surface_text: and on the termination of his life interest, the property vested in the plaintiff as the heir of the late Raja. In the alternative the case put forward was that even if Dhuj Singh had an absolute interest created in his favour under the terms of his fathers will, the plaintiff was entitled to succeed to the taluqdari properties at any rate, under the provision of section 14 b  read with section 22  5  of the Oudh Estates Act.

facts.text: Defendant claimed will vested properties in her after Dhuj Singh's death as his personal heir.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant in her written statement resisted the plaintiffs claim primarily on the ground that Bisheshwar Bux Singh, as the full owner of the properties, was companypetent to dispose of them in any way he liked and under his will it was the defendant and number the plaintiff in whom the properties vested after the death of Dhuj Singh.

facts.text: Trial court held Dhuj Singh got life interest, successive life estates to his heirs, defendant entitled during life, suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt after an elaborate companysideration of the different portions of the will, viewed in the light of surrounding circumstances, came to the companyclusion that Dhuj Singh got a life interest in the devised properties but there were similar life estates created in favour of his personal heirs in succession, the ultimate remainder being given to the holder of the estate when the line of personal heirs would become extinct. The defendant, therefore, was held entitled to the suit properties so long as she was alive and in that view the plaintiffs suit was dismissed.

facts.text: Chief Court of Avadh affirmed trial court decision and dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision, the plaintiff took an appeal to the Chief Court of Avadh and the Chief Court affirmed the decision of the trial judge and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Dhuj Singh had only life interest under the will.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the companyrts below were right in holding that Dhuj Singh had only a life interest in the properties under the terms of his fathers will.

facts.text: Will imposed no right of transfer on Dhuj Singh and heirs.

anchor.surface_text: So that after my death Dhuj Singh may remain in possession of those villages as an absolute owner with the reservation that he will have numberright of transfer.

facts.text: Properties to revert to estate if Dhuj Singh's line becomes extinct.

anchor.surface_text: Of companyrse if Dhuj Singh or his heirs become ever heirless then the said villages will number escheat to the Government but will revert and form part of the estate.

issues.text: whether Dhuj Singh got an absolute estate or an estate for life in the properties given to him by the will of Raja Bisheshwar

anchor.surface_text: The questions, therefore, which require consideration in this case are really two in number. The first is whether Dhuj Singh got an absolute estate or an estate for life in the properties given to, him by the will of Raja Bisheshwar?

arguments.claim: Section 11 of Oudh Estates Act confers wide powers on taluqdar to bequeath limited interests or future estates.

anchor.surface_text: Section. 11 of the Oudh Estates Act companyfers very wide powers of disposition upon a taluqdar and he is companypetent under the section to transfer the whole or any portion of his estate, or of his right and interest therein, [...] and to bequeath by his will to any person the whole or any portion of such estate,

arguments.claim: Total restraint on alienation consistent with life estate intent, displaces presumption of absolute ownership from words like 'absolute owner'.

anchor.surface_text: The clause in the will imposing total restraint -on alienation is also a pointer in the same direction. In cases where the intention of the testator is to grant an absolute estate, an attempt to reduce the powers of the owner by imposing restraint on alienation would certainly be repelled on the ground of repugnancy

arguments.court_reasoning: Courts below right on life interest for Dhuj Singh.

holdings.text: Section 14 of the Oudh Estates Act has no application where the will creates only a life interest and not absolute ownership in the legatee falling under section 13-A(1).

anchor.surface_text: But section 14 would have noapplication if the disposition by the will did number make Dhuj Singh an absolute owner of the properties and he was given only an interest for life which was followed by subsequent interests created in favour of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Argument under s.14 presupposes absolute interest in Dhuj Singh, but primary issue is nature of interest created by will; s.14 regulates succession only for absolute transfers to specified persons.

holdings.text: A taluqdar governed by the Oudh Estates Act is competent to create limited interests or future estates by will, less than absolute proprietary rights.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot also be contended that a taluqdar governed by the Oudh Estates Act cannot convey anything less than his absolute proprietary right in a property by transfer inter vivos or by will, or that it is number companypetent for him to create any limited interest or future estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 11 confers wide disposition powers; s.13/13A formalities do not limit to absolute interests.

holdings.text: Section 12 of the Oudh Estates Act permits creation of future estates and limitations by taluqdars provided they do not transgress the rule against perpetuity.

anchor.surface_text: section 12 of the Act which makes the rule against perpetuity applicable to transfers made by a taluqdar, furnishes a clear indication that the Act does number interdict the creation of future estates and limitations provided they do number trans- gress the perpetuity rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of perpetuity rule implies contemplation of limited/future interests not violating it.

holdings.text: Dhuj Singh took only a life interest under his father's will, not an absolute estate.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the companyrts below were right in holding that Dhuj Singh had only a life interest in the properties under the terms of his fathers will.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will read as whole shows intent for provision to Dhuj Singh's lineal heirs successively without alienation power; 'absolute owner' and 'generation after generation' displaced by context, restraint on transfer, and reversion clause.

holdings.text: Total restraint on alienation is consistent with and supports life estate interpretation, displacing presumption of absolute ownership.

anchor.surface_text: The clause in the will imposing total restraint -on alienation is also a pointer in the same direction. In cases where the intention of the testator is to grant an absolute estate, an attempt to reduce the powers of the owner by imposing restraint on alienation would certainly be repelled on the ground of repugnancy

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repugnancy doctrine does not apply where restraint is primary intent and consistent with limited estate tenor.

holdings.text: Gift of successive life estates to heirs as a class or series is valid with respect to persons in existence at testator's death (here, the widow), invalid for unborn.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite true that numberinterest companyld be created in favour of an unborn person but when the gift is made to a class or series of persons, some of  1  18 Weekly Report 359. whom are in existence and some are number, it does number fail in its entirety it is valid with regard to the persons who are in existence at the time of the testators death and is invalid as to the rest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Tagore v. Tagore; class gift good for ascertained/existing members at vesting, bad for unborn; widow as existing personal heir takes life interest.

anchor.surface_text: and he relies on the case of Tagore v. Tagore 1 . precedents.cited_holding: it does number fail in its entirety it is valid with regard to the persons who are in existence at the time of the testators death and is invalid as to the rest

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the courts below were right in holding that Dhuj Singh had only a life interest in the properties under the terms of his fathers will. Of course this by itself gives no comfort to the defendant she has to establish, in order that she may be able to resist the plaintiffs claim, that the will created an independent interest in her favour following the death of Dhuj Singh. As we have said already, the testator did intend to create successive life estates in favour of the successive heirs of Dhuj Singh.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the courts below were right in holding that Dhuj Singh had only a life interest in the properties under the terms of his fathers will. Of course this by itself gives no comfort to the defendant she has to establish, in order that she may be able to resist the plaintiffs claim, that the will created an independent interest in her favour following the death of Dhuj Singh. As we have said already, the testator did intend to create successive life estates in favour of the successive heirs of Dhuj Singh.

edges.explanation: h2 on competence to create limited interests supports h1's holding that s.14 does not apply to such life interests under s.13-A

anchor.surface_text: It cannot also be contended that a taluqdar governed by the Oudh Estates Act cannot convey anything less than his absolute proprietary right in a property by transfer inter vivos or by will, or that it is number companypetent for him to create any limited interest or future estate.

We hold, therefore, that the courts below were right in holding that Dhuj Singh had only a life interest in the properties under the terms of his fathers will. Of course this by itself gives no comfort to the defendant she has to establish, in order that she may be able to resist the plaintiffs claim, that the will created an independent interest in her favour following the death of Dhuj Singh. As we have said already, the testator did intend to create successive life estates in favour of the successive heirs of Dhuj Singh.

We hold, therefore, that the courts below were right in holding that Dhuj Singh had only a life interest in the properties under the terms of his fathers will. Of course this by itself gives no comfort to the defendant she has to establish, in order that she may be able to resist the plaintiffs claim, that the will created an independent interest in her favour following the death of Dhuj Singh. As we have said already, the testator did intend to create successive life estates in favour of the successive heirs of Dhuj Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The clause in the will imposing total restraint -on alienation is also a pointer in the same direction. In cases where the intention of the testator is to grant an absolute estate, an attempt to reduce the powers of the owner by imposing restraint on alienation would certainly be repelled on the ground of repugnancy

We hold, therefore, that the courts below were right in holding that Dhuj Singh had only a life interest in the properties under the terms of his fathers will. Of course this by itself gives no comfort to the defendant she has to establish, in order that she may be able to resist the plaintiffs claim, that the will created an independent interest in her favour following the death of Dhuj Singh. As we have said already, the testator did intend to create successive life estates in favour of the successive heirs of Dhuj Singh.
